# Random Variables

A random variable is a mathematical object that describes the possible outcomes, and their probabilities, of a random experiment. They are used to create a *model* of the behaviour of random processes, stated formally and algebraically. Random variables take a defined list or range of *numerical* values, either *discrete* or *continuous*.

Random variables are notated using *capital letters*, such as $X$ and $Y$, whilst *specific values* that they can take are notated with small letters such as $x$ and $y$. Time spent paying careful attention to which is required when first encountering random variables will help greatly as the course progresses.

### Discrete Random Variables {-}

If a random variable takes *discrete* numerical values, and a probability is assigned to each, then it is a **discrete random variable**. The outcomes are often integers, but this not necessary, and whilst discrete numbers are often described as ones that can be *"listed"*, the list does not have to be finite. Some examples of discrete random variables are:

\begin{center}
\renewcommand{\arraystretch}{2}
\begin{tabular}{ l  l } 
     \textbf{Random variable} (e.g. $X$) & \textbf{Discrete values} (e.g. $x$)     \\ 
     The outcome of a roll of a cubical die & $1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6$     \\ 
     The number of goals scored in a game of football & $0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7...$     \\ 
     The value of a randomly picked UK coin, in pounds & $0.01,0.02,0.05,0.1,0.2,0.5,1,2$     \\ 
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\pagebreak

## Probability Distributions for Discrete Random Variables

A *probability function*, or *pf*, assigns probabilities to each possible value of a discrete random variable, and there are a number of ways of presenting the *probability distribution* created. For example, consider a discrete random variable $X$ that takes the value $3$ with probability $0.2$, the value $4$ with probability $0.5$ and the value $5$ with probability $0.3$. \begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} The probability distribution table for the discrete random variable $D$ is below.

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ c | c c c c c }
      $d$ & $6$ & $7$ & $8$ & $9$ & $10$\\
  \hline
      $P(D=d)$ & $0.35$ & $0.3$ & $c$ & $0.2$ & $0.1$ 
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\text{(a)   }Calculate the value of $c$.\\
  \\
\text{(b)   }Calculate $P(D\leqslant7)$.\\
  \\
\text{(c)   }Calculate $P(D>7)$.

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}  \\

\text{(a)   }$c=1-(0.35+0.3+0.2+0.1)=0.05$

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ c | c c c c c }
      $d$ & $6$ & $7$ & $8$ & $9$ & $10$\\
  \hline
      $P(D=d)$ & $0.35$ & $0.3$ & $0.05$ & $0.2$ & $0.1$ 
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

\begin{flalign*}
\text{(b)   }P(D\leqslant7)&=P(D=6)+P(D=7) &\\
&=0.35+0.3\\
&=0.65
\end{flalign*}

\end{flalign*}

## The Expectation of a Discrete Random Variable

Whilst a single roll of a die is equally likely to land on any of the numbers from 1 to 6, if it is rolled many times and the *mean* of the observed values is calculated, it is very likely to be around 3.5. Letting random variable $X$ represent the result of one roll of the die, the *long-run mean of successive observations of $X$ will tend to 3.5*. This can be referred to as the *mean*, $\mu$, of $X$, the *expectation* of $X$, or $\text{E}(X)$.

\begin{centering}
\tcbset{width=10cm}
\begin{tcolorbox}[adjusted title=The expectation $\mu$ of discrete random variable $X$:, halign title = center,colback=black!5,colframe=black!75, halign = center]
$\text{E}(X)=\sum{x_iP(X=x_i)}$
\end{tcolorbox}
\end{centering}

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example 1,title filled, colframe=black!50,height=6cm]
\textbf{Problem:} The probability distribution of random variable $X$ is tabulated as: 

\begin{center}
\bgroup
\def\arraystretch{1.5}
\begin{tabular}{ c | c c c c }
      $x$ & $3$ & $4$ & $5$ & $6$\\
  \hline
      $P(X=x)$ & $\frac{1}{8}$ & $\frac{1}{4}$ & $\frac{1}{2}$ & $\frac{1}{8}$ 
\end{tabular}
\egroup
\end{center}

\vspace{-0.5cm}

Calculate $\text{E}(X)$.

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}
$$\text{E}(X) = 3\times \frac{1}{8} + 4\times \frac{1}{4} + 5\times \frac{1}{2} + 6\times \frac{1}{8}= \frac{37}{8}$$

\end{tcolorbox}

## The Law of Expectation

If discrete random variable $X$ takes values ${x_1,x_2...x_n}$ with probabilities $P(X=x_i)$, then random variable \mbox{$Y=2X$} takes values ${2x_1,2x_2...2x_n}$ with probabilities $P(X=x_i)$. For example, let $X$ represent the roll of a die:

\begin{figure}[H]
  \centering
\captionsetup[figure]{labelformat=empty}%
\begin{minipage}{.45\textwidth}
\centering
\begin{center}
\bgroup
\def\arraystretch{1.5}
\begin{tabular}{ c | c c c c c c }
      $x$ & $1$ & $2$ & $3$ & $4$ & $5$ & $6$\\
  \hline
      $P(X=x)$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ 
\end{tabular}
\egroup
\end{center}
\captionof{figure}{$\text{E}(X)=1\times \frac{1}{6}+...+6\times \frac{1}{6}=3.5$}
  \label{fig:test1}
\end{minipage}%
  \centering
\begin{minipage}{.1\textwidth}
  \centering
\end{minipage}%
  \centering
\begin{minipage}{.45\textwidth}
  \centering
\begin{center}
\bgroup
\def\arraystretch{1.5}
\begin{tabular}{ c | c c c c c c }
      $y$ & $2$ & $4$ & $6$ & $8$ & $10$ & $12$\\
  \hline
      $P(Y=y)$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ & $\frac{1}{6}$ 
\end{tabular}
\egroup
\end{center}
\captionof{figure}{$\text{E}(2X)=\text{E}(Y)=2\times \frac{1}{6}+...+12\times \frac{1}{6}=7$}
  \label{fig:test1}
\end{minipage}
\end{figure}

(Note that the distribution of $2X$ is *not* that of the sum of two *independent* dice rolls.)

It can be seen here that $\text{E}(2X)=2\text{E}(X)$. The expectation of a random variable that is a *linear transformation* of another random variable for which the expectation is known can be calculated using the law:

\begin{centering}
\tcbset{width=10cm}
\begin{tcolorbox}[adjusted title=For random variable $X$ with constants $a$ and $b$:, halign title = center,colback=black!5,colframe=black!75, halign = center]
$\text{E}(aX\pm b)=a\text{E}(X)\pm b$
\end{tcolorbox}
\end{centering}

Proof:

\begin{align*}
    \text{E}(aX+ b)&=\sum{(ax_i + b)\text{P}(X=x_i)}\\
    &=\sum{(ax_i)\text{P}(X=x_i)}+ \sum{b{\text{P}(X=x_i)}}\\
    &=a\sum{x_i\text{P}(X=x_i)}+ b\sum{\text{P}(X=x_i)}\\
    &=a\text{E}(X)+ b
\end{align*}

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example 1,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} Let $X$ be the random variable such that $\text{E}(X)=3$. Calculate $\text{E}(4X-1)$.

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}

\vspace{-0.8cm}
\begin{align*}
\text{E}(4X-1)&=4\text{E}(X)-1\\
&=4\times 3-1\\
&=11
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example 2,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} Given tht $\text{E}(10-2Y)=50$, determine the value of $\text{E}(Y)$.
\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}

\vspace{-0.8cm}
\begin{align*}
\text{E}(10-2Y)&=50\\
\text{E}(-2Y+10)&=50\\
-2\text{E}(Y)+10&=50\\
-2\text{E}(Y)&=40\\
\text{E}(Y)&=-20
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}

## The Variance of a Random Variable

The *variance* of the values observed from successive rolls of a fair cubical die will tend towards a value in the long-run. Letting the random variable $X$ represent the result of a roll of a die, the **variance**, $\sigma^2$, of $X$ is $\frac{35}{12}$, or $\text{V}(X)=\frac{35}{12}$.

\begin{centering}
\tcbset{width=10cm}
\begin{tcolorbox}[adjusted title=The variance $\sigma^2$ of random variable $X$:, halign title = center,colback=black!5,colframe=black!75, halign = center]
$\text{V}(X)=\text{E}(X^2)-E^2(X)$
\end{tcolorbox}
\end{centering}

Proof:

\begin{align*}
    \text{V}(X)&=\text{E}[(X-\mu)^2]\\
    &=\text{E}[(X-\mu)(X-\mu)]\\
    &=\text{E}[X^2-2\mu X+\mu^2]\\
    &=\text{E}(X^2)-2\mu \text{E}(X)+\mu^2\\
    &=\text{E}(X^2)-2(\text{E}(X))^2 +(\text{E}(X))^2\\
    &=\text{E}(X^2)-\text{E}^2(X)
\end{align*}

Knowing the *expectation* and *variance* of random variables help statisticians better understand the *long-run* behaviour of repeated observations:

\begin{itemize}
    \item $\text{E}(X)=\mu$, the \textit{long-run mean} of the distribution of $X$.
    \item $\text{V}(X)=\sigma^2$, the \textit{variance} of the distribution of $X$.
\end{itemize}

The standard deviation, $\sigma$, of a random variable $X$, notated $\text{SD}(X)$, is the square root of the variance:

$$\text{SD}(X)=\sqrt{\text{V}(X)}\qquad\text{and}\qquad \text{SD}(X),\text{V}(X)\geqslant0$$

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} The probability distribution of random variable $X$ is tabulated as: 

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ c | c c c c }
      $x$ & $0$ & $1$ & $2$ & $3$\\
  \hline
      $P(X=x)$ & $0.3$ & $0.4$ & $0.1$ & $0.2$ 
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

Calculate $\text{E}(X)$ and $\text{V}(X)$

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}\textit{ (Remember that $\text{E}(X^2)$ is not the variance.)}

\vspace{-0.3cm}
\begin{align*}
\text{E}(X) &= 0\times 0.3 + 1\times 0.4 + 2\times 0.1 + 3\times 0.2= 1.2\\[1em]
\text{E}(X^2) &= 0^2\times 0.3 + 1^2\times 0.4 + 2^2\times 0.1 + 3^2\times 0.2= 2.6\\[1em]
\text{V}(X) &= \text{E}(X^2)-E^2(X)\\
&= 2.6 - 1.2^2\\
&= 1.16
\end{align*}

\end{tcolorbox}

## The Law of Variance

Since variance is a measure of variability based on *squared* differences, $\text{V}(2X)\ne2\text{V}(X)$.

\begin{centering}
\tcbset{width=10cm}
\begin{tcolorbox}[adjusted title=For random variable $X$ with constants $a$ and $b$:, halign title = center,colback=black!5,colframe=black!75, halign = center]
$\text{V}(aX\pm b)=a^2\text{V}(X)$
\end{tcolorbox}
\end{centering}

Proof:

\begin{align*}
    \text{V}(aX+ b)&=\text{E}[((aX+ b)-(\text{E}(aX+ b))^2]\\
    &=\text{E}[(aX+b-a\text{E}(X)-b)^2]\\
    &=\text{E}[(aX-a\text{E}(X))^2]\\
    &=\text{E}[(a(X-\text{E}(X)))^2]\\
    &=\text{E}[a^2(X-\text{E}(X))^2]\\
    &=a^2 \text{E}[(X-\text{E}(X))^2]\\
    &=a^2 \text{V}(X)
\end{align*}

Note that any laws relating to the *standard deviation* of a linear transformation ($\text{SD}(aX\pm b)$) would not be able to be expressed so concisely, so such problems must be tackled by *first finding the variance* ($\text{V}(aX\pm b)$).

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example 1,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} Let $X$ be the random variable such that $\text{E}(X)=-7$ and $\text{V}(X)=4$. Calculate $\text{V}(2-3X)$.

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}\textit{ (It helps to rearrange into the form $aX\pm b$.)}

\begin{align*}
\text{V}(2-3X)&=\text{V}(-3X+2)\\
&=(-3)^2\text{V}(X)\\
&=9\times 4\\
&=36\\
\end{align*}
\end{tcolorbox}

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example 2,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} Random variable $Y$ has mean 1.5 and standard deviation 0.8.\\ Determine the standard deviation of $10Y+25$.

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}

\begin{align*}
\text{V}(10Y+25)&=10^2\text{V}(Y)\\
&=100\times 0.8^2\\
&=64\\
\text{SD}&=8\\
\end{align*}
\end{tcolorbox}

## Bivariate Random Variables

As well as linear transformations of a single random variable, new variables can be created by adding (or subtracting) random variables. Given random variables $X$ and $Y$, for example, $W=X+Y$ is a \textit{bivariate} random variable. When studying the long-run behaviour of bivariate random variables, by considering their expectation and variance, it is important to consider whether the variables are **independent**.

\begin{centering}
\tcbset{width=14cm}
\begin{tcolorbox}[adjusted title=For \textbf{independent} random variables $X$ and $Y$:, halign title = center,colback=black!5,colframe=black!75, halign = center]
\vspace{-0.3cm}
\begin{equation*}
  \begin{split}
    \text{E}(X+Y) &= \text{E}(X)+\text{E}(Y)\\[10pt]
    \text{E}(X-Y) &= \text{E}(X)-\text{E}(Y)\\[10pt]
    \text{E}(aX\pm bY) &= a\text{E}(X)\pm b\text{E}(Y)
  \end{split}
\quad\text{ and }\quad
  \begin{split}
    \text{V}(X+Y) &= \text{V}(X)+\text{V}(Y)\\[10pt]
    \text{V}(X-Y) &= \text{V}(X)+\text{V}(Y)\\[10pt]
    \text{V}(aX\pm bY) &= a^2\text{V}(X)+ b^2\text{V}(Y)
  \end{split}
\end{equation*}

\end{tcolorbox}
\end{centering}

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example 1,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} Two independent random variables $F$ and $G$ have means of 15 and 12 and standard deviations of 3 and 4 respectively. Calculate $\text{E}(3G-2F)$ and $\text{V}(F-G)$.

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}\text{ ($\text{E}(X)=15,\text{E}(Y)=12,\text{SD}(X)=3,\text{SD}(Y)=4$)}

\vspace{-1.2cm}
\begin{multicols}{2}
\null\vfill
\begin{align*}
\text{E}(3G-2F)&=3\text{E}(G)-2\text{E}(F)\\
&=3\times 12 - 2\times 15\\
&=36-30\\
&=6
\end{align*}
\vfill\null
\columnbreak
\null\vfill
\begin{align*}
\text{V}(F)&=3^2=9\\
\text{V}(G)&=4^2=16\\
\text{V}(F-G)&=\text{V}(F)+\text{V}(G)\\
&=9+16\\
&=25
\end{align*}
\vfill\null
\end{multicols}

\end{tcolorbox}

\begin{tcolorbox}[title=Example 2,title filled, colframe=black!50]
\textbf{Problem:} Books in the fiction section of a library have a mean thickness of 3.1cm with standard deviation 0.2cm. If three books are randomly selected from the fiction section and stacked together, determine the mean and standard deviation of the collected, total thickness of the three books, stating one assumption required.

\tcblower
\textbf{Solution:}

Let random variable $X$ represent the thickness of a book, so $\text{E}(X)=3.1$ and $\text{V}(X)=0.2^2=0.04$\\\vskip 0.2cm

Total thickness $T=X_1+X_2+X_3$. Assuming that the thickness of each book is independent:\\\vskip 0.1cm

$\text{E}(T)=\text{E}(X_1+X_2+X_3)=\text{E}(X_1)+\text{E}(X_2)+\text{E}(X_3)=3.1+3.1+3.1=9.3$\\\vskip 0.1cm

$\text{V}(T)=\text{V}(X_1+X_2+X_3)=\text{V}(X_1)+\text{V}(X_2)+\text{V}(X_3)=0.04+0.04+0.04=0.12$\\\vskip 0.1cm

$\text{SD}(T)=\sqrt{\text{V}(T)}=\sqrt{0.12}=0.346$\\\vskip 0.1cm

Hence the mean total thickness of the three books is 9.3cm, and the standard deviation is 0.346cm.

\end{tcolorbox}
